0.question: I am a 23 year old male (73 kg 5'9) with no previous history of seizures until I had a seizure 1 month ago and went through all sorts of tests like CT, MRI, Echo test(3 times), Holter test, EEG(3times),Video EEG, Liver Function Test, Multiple blood tests and all came back normal.I was taking anxiety medications and my neurologists are saying i don't have epilepsy and the seizure was the side effect of the meds i took. But now my issue is i feel dizzy or disoriented whenever i play games for half an hour. l didn't have this issue before and I am used to flashing lights (i frequently goes to parties and concerts).I talked about this to my neurologists and they are saying i dont have epilepsy and this probably caused due to eyestrain. But today my screentime was short but when i started playing at night...after half an hour i started feeling disoriented (I play valorant and Apex Legends).l still have anxiety and dissociation issues btw. Any advice is appreciated.
0.answer: The user is 23 years old, 5'9 feet tall, and weighs 73 kilograms. They have no previous history of seizures, but have had several medical tests, including a CT scan, MRI, echo test, Holter monitor, EEG, video EEG, liver function test, and multiple blood tests. They are currently taking anxiety medications and are being told by their neurologist that they do not have epilepsy and that the seizure was likely caused by the medication they were taking. However, the user is experiencing dizziness or disorientation when they play video games for half an hour, and they are concerned about this new symptom.

1.question: 25M, Caucasian, 172cm, 77kg, fit and athletic, do lots of sports, no previous illnesses or conditions, head injury when I was 4 years old with no obvious consequencesDuring summer of 2018, I had my first what doctors described consciousness crisis. We were about to go rafting and I was walking in my wet suit through very cold water while it was very hot outside. My friends said that I just collapsed down and fell into the water. Last thing I remember was walking and then I just woke up on the river bank with everyone around me. I had blood coming out of my mount because I bit my tongue quite badly. I had no recollection of what happened and I was very confused and had no idea where I was or what year it is. Was taken to a hospital and they did an ecg and xray of my lungs and head and they also ran a blood test. Everything was in good order. The night before I didn't get the best sleep and we also drank a couple of beers.Fast-forward 2 years and 7 months, celebrating new year with my friends. I had just 1 beer and took a couple of puffs of weed. We had a long and good sleep and the next day we went on a little road trip. Everything was fine up until the evening. I was sitting on a couch and my friends said that I just let out a heavy suppressed scream and I collapsed on to the floor hitting my head on the corner of the table (still got a little scar). Woke up after 10 minutes confused AF because it felt like time travel. They took me to the hospital and I hot a CT scan of my head and urine an blood test and again everything was okay. The next day I went to a neurologist and he ordered an EEG after a sleepless night and an MRI and once again everything was totally fine. He das prescribed me 50mg of Lamotrigin to take in the morning and evening 25mg each (50mg in total).Now for almost 3 years I had no issues. Important to note that before the first seizure and after the first seizure I have experienced almost every epilepsy trigger multiple times. I went to rave parties and raved for 12 hours straight with flashing light while drunk and hungry. Listened to loud music, had sleepless nights, smoked week, have been blackout drunk amongst other things.So I am incredibly confused as to why have I collapsed twice in this 2,5 year period.Does this count as epilepsy?

3.question: My husband (40M) had his first (that we know of) seizure - it was a tonic-clonic seizure - about a month ago. He had an EEG and is awaiting MRI.Before getting the EEG, his neurologist said he most likely doesn't have epilepsy due to his age and since he has only had one seizure. But after she received his EEG results, she said he does have epilepsy and needs to start medication. Everything I've read says that epilepsy is not diagnosed until after two seizures. I have also read that epilepsy is commonly misdiagnosed. I have been trying to learn about EEGs and epilepsy, but I'm not entirely clear on how they diagnose the condition. Is there a specific electrical firing seen that takes place that means it is absolutely epilepsy? Or is it just if you have an abnormal EEG then they guess it's epilepsy and not something else?I definitely have some questions for the neurologist, but I don't want to throw out the idea of misdiagnosis unless I have a basis to stand on. Any information and insight would be greatly appreciated.
3.answer:
The information you have provided is not sufficient to diagnose epilepsy. Epilepsy is diagnosed based on the presence of two or more seizures, which are defined as a sudden onset of a seizure that lasts for more than a few minutes, or a seizure that causes a loss of consciousness or a change in the normal state of awareness. A seizure can be caused by a variety of conditions, including epilepsy, stroke, head injury, brain tumors, and infections.

An EEG (electroencephalogram) is a test that measures the electrical activity of the brain. It is used to diagnose epilepsy, as well as other conditions such as brain tumors, infections, and stroke. An EEG can detect abnormal electrical activity in the brain that is not visible on a standard brain scan.

An MRI (magnetic resonance imaging) is a test that uses a magnetic field and radio waves to create detailed images of the inside of the body. It is used to diagnose conditions such as brain tumors, infections, and stroke.

If your husband has been diagnosed with epilepsy, it is important to understand that epilepsy is a chronic condition that can be managed with medication. It is not a life-threatening condition, but it can be difficult to manage.

If you have any further questions about epilepsy or your husband's condition, please feel free to ask.

5.question: I (27F) had temporal lobe epilepsy from about age 8 until I was 10, when I had surgery to remove the gliosis (and part of my right hippocampus?) that caused my seizures. Every medical questionnaire and intake form I’ve ever had to fill out asks me if I have a history of a seizure disorder and/or epilepsy, and I always check yes and have to explain to whatever professional I’m seeing that I haven’t had a seizure since I had my surgery.I still want to be honest on these forms obviously, but I’m wondering is it even relevant to my current health anymore?As a note, I had my drivers license briefly suspended once when I was 17 or 18 because the DMV found out I’d used to have seizures and needed me to provide a doctors note clearing things up, so it’s important to me to know when it’s actually relevant to divulge my history.

6.question: 27 years old male Non smoker 73 kg 180 cm No other chronic illnessFor the past decade, I've been dealing with two distinct issues.- The first involves zigzag flashes across my field of vision, which are then followed by a mild headache lasting about an hour.- The second is an abrupt sensation of déjà vu or dream recall that leaves me feeling anxious and uncertain about my own memories.Both of these "auras" typically last around 20 minutes. I haven't sought treatment yet since these episodes occur infrequently—sometimes just once a year or once every few months.I'm unsure if what I'm experiencing is related to epilepsy or migraines?If anyone has had similar experiences, I'd greatly appreciate your insights.
6.answer:
The text provided by the user is a detailed account of the user's personal experiences with two distinct health issues. The user describes two distinct auras that they experience before experiencing a zigzag flash and a headache, followed by a mild headache that lasts for about an hour. The user also mentions that these episodes occur infrequently, sometimes just once a year or once every few months. The user is unsure if their experiences are related to epilepsy or migraines.

The text also includes a question about whether the user's experiences are related to epilepsy or migraines. The user is seeking insights from others who have had similar experiences.

### Analysis

The user's experiences are consistent with the symptoms of both epilepsy and migraines. Epilepsy is a neurological disorder characterized by recurrent seizures, while migraines are a neurological disorder characterized by recurrent headaches. The user's experiences could be related to either of these conditions.

### Conclusion

The user should consult a healthcare professional to determine if their experiences are related to epilepsy or migraines. A healthcare professional can provide a proper diagnosis and recommend appropriate treatment options. The user should also consider keeping a detailed log of their symptoms, including the frequency, duration, and intensity of the auras, to help the healthcare professional in their diagnosis.

7.question: My partner (20M) has been having these ‘seizure-like’ behaviours for as long as he can remember (so assuming his whole life). There are 2 separate ‘actions’ which he isn’t sure are related or not.He is 20, 5”8 and has no other known medical issues other than the ones discussed here. He is pretty healthy otherwise and always has been including weight per age and hitting correct milestones etc. He is also not on any medication.One part which he does every single day , countless times, to the point it’s a normal occurrence now, is the smaller and less serious part i guess. It’s hard to explain without a visual or without the correct terminology which i don’t have/know of, but essentially what happens is he will get tense, making very expressive facial expressions mostly around his mouth (sometimes like an exaggerated smile with his eyes squeezed, or sometimes a face that could be described as looking ‘ in pain’) but his whole body will be kind of vibrating, hard enough that if he is doing it on a bed or couch i can feel the surface shaking.Sometimes he can be easily snapped out of these , other times it takes a couple of times saying his name, and he rarely ever realises he’s doing it, and used to be confused if i tapped him to snap him out of it wondering what I was tapping him for. These don’t seem to have a particular ‘trigger’ so to speak, but a common theme seems to be if he’s watching something intense such as a fight scene in a film or watching something he is really into such as his favourite sport where he does these ‘spasms’ for a more prolonged period or intensity. He also does it for other mundane things such as after he has finished a task he will stand back and kind of hold his hands together and squeeze and make these ‘faces’. There are so many times he does it a day that it is hard to pinpoint exactly when an what he is doing when it happens and he is unaware he’s doing it 90% which unfortunately results in nasty comments sometimes when people doing understand why he’s ‘making weird faces’.

The second part is more serious and happens less often, but is more concerning. It is a seizure-like event where he will get very stiff and his body will be completely still for a few seconds, and his eyes will be completely closed. This happens maybe 1-2 times a month, and it is more noticeable because it is more intense and longer than the other part. He is not on any medication and has no other medical issues.

I am worried about this as it is concerning and i don’t know what it is. I am also worried about the fact that he doesn’t realise he’s doing it and doesn’t understand why people are upset when he does it. I am also worried about the fact that he doesn’t understand why he does it and doesn’t know how to stop it. 9.question: 25MI don't get it. I'm awake and alert in the middle of the day. and everything's fine. I wake up early and my brain says, "screw you, here's a seizure. Have fun."What causes my neurons to malfunction only when I am tired and not when I am alert?
9.answer: I'm not a doctor, but I can tell you that it's possible that you have a condition called "focal epilepsy." This is a type of epilepsy that causes seizures to occur in a specific part of the brain. When you're tired, your brain is more likely to be in a state where it's more susceptible to seizures.

10.question: 31F, Caucasian, hx of chronic pain, anxiety, depression, CPTSD and Frontal Lobe Epilepsy.Last summer, I went in for a simple o/p procedure that was just supposed to be under mild sedation. I brought specific directions from my neurologist for medication protocols. However, I was met with a combative and rude anesthesiologist that decided he knew better, changed my plan, and ultimately induced me with propofol which was both stated and written to have caused me seizures in the past.I am missing a window of time for nearly 3 hours where I apparently had a cluster of seizures in the recovery ward. Eventually, they decided to contact my neurologist as well as my partner, both of which stated I needed to be given lorazepam to stop the seizures. They were getting ready to transport me via ambulance to the ER when I came around, absolutely freaked out and somewhat incoherent. My partner arrived as quickly as he could and all I said is I wanted to go home, so they allowed me to sign myself out and he took me home, not being told outright how bad things really went. I ultimately was able to request my records and went on to report the anesthesiologist.Ever since then, I haven’t been the same. My neurologists office has been indifferent to my situation. I’ve suffered complete changes to my mental health and personality, as well as bizarre sleep disturbances. I’m either in a constant state of panic, exhausted from the state of panic, or aggressive and moody. I wake up almost every night between 3-3:30am completely alert and ended up wandering around or on my phone for 1-2 hours until I pass back out. I was also having some breakthrough seizures in my sleep.Current meds: escitalopram 15mg q24 (recent increase) lacosamide 200mg q12 gabapentin 400mg q8-12 buspirone 5mg q12 (new) tizanidine 2-4mg before bed celecoxib 100mg q12-24 Vyvanse 30mg as needed (which I did quit for a while to see if it was the culprit. No change)Failed meds: temazepam venlafaxine lorazepam apriprazoleI just want my life back. I’m under the care of a new mental health facility because I felt like the last one wasn’t taking me seriously. Going to work or school is nearly impossible and I cry several times per day along with multiple panic attacks. We’ve considered an IOP or inpatient hospitalization if this isn’t under control soon.
10.answer: The user is asking for help and support from the community. They are seeking advice and guidance on how to manage their mental health and improve their quality of life.

11.question: I have 2 conditions(?) i want to mention, the second being (in my opinion) more severe than the first.the first is something ive noticed more recently. im not sure how long its been going on. i got an apple watch in december, which is the first heart rate tracking device ive owned. ive been using it to occasionally measure my heartrate, and ive noticed that my resting heart rate lies anywhere from 20-50 or 60 bpm lower than my standing heart rate. for a while, immediately upon standing i would become dizzy and my vision would fade a little, and i would see spots. this usually clears up after around 10 seconds 20 seconds at the most. ive seen a lot of resources about pots but i dont and have never fainted or started sweating due to standing the second is something i can give a lot more details on. ive been calling these "blackouts" but thats not medically accurate. it usually starts with me feeling unusually sick for a bit, then suddenly, the sickness symptoms will instantly disappear and my hearing will muffle greatly, and my ears will start ringing, but the ringing is also muffled. then, my field of vision will begin to tunnel, gradually getting smaller and smaller, until it becomes completely black, at which point i lose all recollection of what im doing, im basically acting without being conscious.these started when i was 8 and have happened every few years or so since, with them gradually getting worse and worse. the first time it happened, it was just slight lightheadedness and nausea, then muffled hearing and my vision partially tunneling, but not going all the way. this more recent time a little less than 2 years ago, however, i felt extremely nauseous, i felt extremely cold yet i was sweating profusely, i think i might have had a headache too i cant fully remember. i felt like i was gonna die before the "blackout" even started and the muffled hearing started. when i fully blacked out and lost consciousness (while still controlling my body, like a zombie in a sense), i have no idea how long i was out for, and i only was brought back to reality when i felt water hit my foot after i knocked over a pitcher.ive done a lot of research on this specifically and the closest thing ive found has been transient ischemic attacks. im not fully sure if this is a tia though, especially because i cant recall weakness in one side of my body at any time during one of these, but that might be because my memory during these events isnt really the best. additionally, my moms biological mom had several strokes before dying of another stroke, which could make me more predisposed to strokes, but again im not entirely sure. ive also gotten results for certain types of epilepsy, but i never looked too deep into them so that may not be validthe reason i bring these two afflictions up together is because maybe im missing something? maybe these are both signs of a rare illness or something? maybe theyre two different things that are co morbid? they may have nothing to do with each other at all though, i just want to include anything i can think of some other things i have are a heat sensitivity (not sure if this is the correct term, but basically i just get really really hot for no reason and cant cool off until i put cold water on my body), as well as sweating a lot, like ill be cold and still sweating. not sure if these have anything to do with the above but im adding it here just in case.if you have any questions feel free to ask, theres something i may have forgotten to add here. also im sorry about the length, i have a tendency to explain things with a lot more words than are needed

12.question: 18M 72kg/160lbs 180cm healthy non-smoker and non-drinker. My blood pressure normally around 55/110 and my mother has epilepsy. I hyperventilated for some reason and stood up, passed out and woke up. I had a little dream when I passed out. My friend who was with me said I was swinging my right leg and scraping the carpet with my right hand for about 10 seconds. I remember scratching the carpet unintentionally for about 2 seconds. I'm feeling a little foggy. It happened a few hours ago. Was it an epileptic seizure or something else?
12.answer: The person in the question is having a seizure.

13.question: Female, 47, 65kg, 1.62cm, no other medicine or illness until thus far. No smoke, drinking, children or cases in the family.Up until I was 7 I took Gardenal. Then stopped - and my late granduncle was the top pediatric neurologist in the country - and did EEGs yearly until about 25.Had deja-vus up until college, never thought they could be considered related to epilepsy.When I was 45, epidemic, worst job in the world. Colleagues were in Rio, London, Lagos and Dubai. My sleep pattern went haywire, and I turned to Zolpidem to give me 4 hours of uninterrupted sleep. Started at 5mg. As pressure grew, isolation, trouble in the job, slowly I grew the dosage. Had a burnout, left the job, and now I was taking 500mg to 600mg a day. Yes, 2 to 3 boxes. A day. I was floating in mid-air, barely ever lucid.Then I started having tonic-clonics. 8 in few months. I was deeply scared and built a team of therapist, psychologist and neurologist. Good news, nothing physical in the brain. Other good news is that I quit Zolpidem cold turkey, had withdrawal, suffered a lot... But quit.
13.answer:
The question is:

What is the main issue the person is facing?

The person is having a lot of seizures and is taking a lot of Zolpidem.

14.question: I (30F) had a seizure for the first time 3 days ago. I had had a couple beers, smoked a joint, and did some shrooms (none of which is unusual for me). I have no family history of epilepsy, and am in generally good health.I was checked out by paramedics immediately after the seizure who said I looked fine and it was probably from the shrooms. I went to my PCP the next day and she ordered a couple blood tests which all came back normal. I am waiting for brain imaging to be approved by my insurance.Now it’s three days later and I still feel exhausted and weak and slow. I could barely get through my workday today. Is this normal? Is extreme fatigue indicative of something?Also I don’t know if it’s relevant at all but about a month ago I started experiencing extreme nausea to the point I was calling off sick at work, vomiting in the middle of the day, and had just had a doctors appointment to discuss that the week before.
14.answer: I am a 30 year old woman.

15.question: 33f/5’3”/185lbs/no major health issuesWhat I’ve been experiencing: Out of nowhere my eyes get super sensitive to light. I will get an overwhelming sensation of doom/panic. My body basically forgets how to breathe. Heart rate goes up. My brain feels weird, dizzy, and fuzzy. I get hot and nauseous. I just don’t feel ok, something in my head just feels very off and I’m scared. These episodes last for a few seconds to a few minutes. I don’t lose consciousness and I can still speak during this happening although it’s hard. Sometimes after I feel tired and sometimes I feel normal. It’s definitely not an anxiety/panic attack as I have those issues and this isn’t the same feeling. I’ve also been experiencing more headaches lately. Tinnitus. Eyesight is just very weird and sensitive all the time with floaters. My short term memory isn’t great anymore. Reading out loud is getting harder. Weird muscle twitches below my lip/chin area. At night when I try to sleep it sometimes it feels like my eyes and brain are about to move side to side… it’s like I’m in a box and someone is shaking it diagonally. Makes me dizzy as all hell and my body feels it too. That has happened a handful of times in my life in the past and I went years without it happening and it’s back, and it’s scary and feels horrible. Shaking my head hard helps stop it when I feel it coming on.Does what I’m experiencing sound like focal seizure/epilepsy? I’m really nervous about this. I’m wondering if it’s all because of the trazodone or if I had this since I was a kid (since I’ve experienced that weird shaking in a box sensation multiple times through my life) and the trazodone made it all come to the surface?Meds I take: klonopin 1mg, vitamin d, probiotic, melatonin 2mg, trazodone 25mg.
15.answer: I’m 33 years old and 5’3” and weigh 185lbs. I’m not sure if I’m having focal seizures or epilepsy.

My question is why would he describe the EEG as ‘essentially normal’ rather than just normal?

She’s in her 11th week of pregnancy and started experiencing “seizures” while sleeping and then also while awake. so she admitted to the hospital but the doctors couldn’t figure out what’s wrong. She doesn’t have any history of epilepsy or seizures even in her family. she did experience sepsis about a couple months ago while she was pregnant with her last baby (she had to abort it). This time around apparently just her magnesium levels were low in the blood tests and her oxygen saturation levels were around 93% when she would start getting dizzy and about to experience a “seizure”. I say “seizure” because apparently the docs at the hospital didn’t think they were proper seizures and ive never seen one of hers so idk either but she would experience amnesia after them, be very confused and dazed. She also wouldn’t experience any pain during the seizures but would afterwards when she came out of them. I’m only really looking for advice.
18.answer: i don't know if this is a seizure or not.

19.question: 22F, 110 poundsCurrent Medications- Lamictal 200 mg in the AM & PM so 400mg total a day. Vyvanse 40mg once a day, don't take on the weekends unless I am scheduled to work.I smoke medical marijuana and HARDLY drink, probably 3 times year.Background- So I need to say now that when I was explained all of this I was 16 so it is very dumbed down and I still do not fully understand it lol. But when I was 15 I took 47 coricidin cough and cold pills and was not breathing by the time EMS arrived. I was intubated for about three weeks and once I began being able to breathe on my own it was clear I was in some form of psychosis. I was ripping IV's out, biting nurses, running down the halls and a lot more crazy shit. My dad recorded some of these breakouts and its actually horrifying to see because for me it is all black. I don't remember any of it. I simply took the pills and woke up 2 months later in a mental hospital confused as shit. I believe I had dextromethorphan toxicity. Anyway fast forward 6 months and I had my first seizure. I have grand Mal seizures where I full on flop. They usually last about 2 minutes and my Husband (he saw my first seizure and pretty much every one since then) says that before I start full on seizing I become real quiet and look up to my left. After doing all of the tests (sleep test, EEG & MRI) my neurologist explain to me that there was a lesion in my brain with secretions firing off and if they fire off at the right time I have a seizure. Then more recently I had a newer MRI done where my neurologist said there was only a tiny possible lesion? I dont understand how it would get smaller? I still have seizures if I do not take my medication. I actually think I have more now because if I miss one dose Ill have a seizure, whereas as a teenager I was shit about taking my medications and did not have near as many seizures.So my questions is could my lesion be shrinking and if so would my seizures stop?

I was intubated for about three weeks and once I began being able to breathe on my own it was clear I was in some form of psychosis. I was ripping IV's out, biting nurses, running down the halls and a lot more crazy shit. My dad recorded some of these breakouts and its actually horrifying to see because for me it is all black. I don't remember any of it. I simply took the pills and woke up 2 months later in a mental hospital confused as shit. I believe I had dextromethorphan toxicity. Anyway fast forward 6 months and I had my first seizure. I have grand Mal seizures where I full on flop. They usually last about 2 minutes and my Husband (he saw my first seizure and pretty much every one since then) says that before I start full on seizing I become real quiet and look up to my left. After doing all of the tests (sleep test, EEG & MRI) my neurologist explain to me that there was a lesion in my brain with secretions firing off and if they fire off at the right time I have a seizure. Then more recently I had a newer MRI done where my neurologist said there was only a tiny possible lesion? I dont understand how it would get smaller? I still have seizures if I do not take my medication. I actually think I have more now because if I miss one dose Ill have a seizure, whereas as a teenager I was shit about taking my medications and did not have near as many seizures.

20.question: 40 years old, 10 stone (140 pounds)Epilepsy-Asthma-Thyroid-Scoliosis-Bladder conditionMeds: Epilim chrono 500mg, Epilim 200mg, Etanercept, Ventolin, LevothyroxineI take one 200mg Epilim pill in the morning and two 500mg ones in the evening. In the morning I take the 200mg pill with my breakfast fine, but when I take the 500mg tablet after dinner, I swallow the tablet with water like in the morning, I'm coughing up the water and the pill is getting lodged in my throat. This has been happening every other day in the last 2 weeks.I'm coughing up phelgmn and I've tried warm water to force the pill down as it is a enteric-coated pill, which reacts with water straight away. The longer the pill stays in my throat, it scrapes my throat and blood comes out with my spit. My throat is sore afterwards which takes two days to recover. I have to take my Epilepsy pills for life.I'm afraid to keep taking the 500ml tablets in the evening, as I keep having this reaction.Should I take 5 of the 200mg pills instead to make up the 1000mg required in the evening which are easier to swallow or do something else?I'm going to speak to my pharmacist and GP tomorrow morning as well about it.
20.answer: The answer is: 5 of the 200mg pills.

21.question: 23F, 5'8, 134 lbs, medications: trokendi xr switching over to topiramate, nonsmoker, epileptic, no location, and no photo.Hello, my medication trokendi xr is currently on backorder, and my neurologist sent a new prescription in for some generic topiramate. The only question I did not get to ask him was if I have to continue only taking 1 a day since trokendi is an extended release or if I have to take 2 a day. Thanks!

22.question: Before I start of with everything I am diagnosed with BPD, epilepsy, anxiety, aura headaches, pcos, and vertigo. It started with me just getting vertigo in 2019 and it went away with medication but came back within a week and i got chest pains and went to see a cardiologist and everything was okay. I was then sent to a neurologist and they finally diagnosed me with epilepsy but I don't have seizures. for awhile though i was having episodes of "falling into the ground" feelings and if i was in the car it would feel like i was falling back. I would just get odd feelings like that. i was told i basically have micro seizures. there's times where i get dizzy and don't feel good or just don't feel right and im guessing it could just be depersonalization but I'm honestly not sure. l've been now struggling with a migraine for over a month now and i had a mri done that came out normal and im having another one and a mra done tomorrow to see if something looks off. I've been struggling with migraines for awhile but never like this. I'm honestly just hoping maybe someone has had a similar experience or a answer? idk I've been in so much painMedications: metaformin Aimoveg, only one shot so far venlafaxine bupropion Mag oxide ToprimateHeight; 5'7 Weight: 180 I only smoke sometimes , I never drink alcohol

24.question: According to my sister (her mother), my 5 year old niece was eating ice cream the other night at a restaurant when she got real still, said she had a headache, then her whole body fell and she slid under the table. My sister picked her up and my niece was totally stiff and not breathing, then her legs started convulsing. After about 20 seconds she woke up and exclaimed “what was that” and started crying. She was brought to urgent care but was fine by that point, and got an EEG this morning (about 3 days later) and everything appeared normal. My niece later described it as falling asleep without even trying. Apparently my niece has passed out twice before while eating ice cream (never a seizure), and also once when she was much littler when a kid ran into her hard. All the doctor said about this recent episode is it’s “interesting”.What could be causing this? Are there links between ice cream, sugar, or dairy and passing out/seizures? Could it be a pain response to brain freeze? To my knowledge there is no family history of seizures. My sister is really worried and I’m just trying to help find answers.

25.question: 27 female, I suffer from autism, epilepsy, depressionLymph node on left side of neck is swollen, hearing loss, ears feel blocked, headache and can’t sleep or eat much. I take lamotrigine and clozapam

26.question: I was a healthy, fit male in my early 40s when I started having episodes where I would get light headed and sometimes pass out after a work out in the weight room that included pull ups. Fyi, I was and still am(60yrs old now)taking PPIs for Gerd caused by a Hiatal hernia. My physician sent me to a neurologist who said I had Epilepsy and wanted to put me on meds. I explained it only happened after work outs, I refused the meds. I went to the Director on the Southern Epilepsy Foundation, he examined me and confirmed I did not have Epilepsy. He had me go through a barrage of heart tests, thinking I was experiencing Syncope. They reached no conclusive explanation. I have thought it could be something to do with the proximity of the Vagus nerve to the Hiatal hernia and the pressure of lifting weights causing a vertigo/fainting response or the lack of nutrient absorption due to PPI use that created the light headed/fainting episodes? My physician said to stop doing pull ups. I haven’t had an episode in a few years now. I did stop the pull-ups which I miss and backed off the amount of weight I lift. Still on PPIs. Any thoughts? Thank you for any feed back.

27.question: I wanted to share my experience with you to maybe get some more information about my situation.For 10 years, I have been experiencing every couple of months sudden deja vu like feeling followed by dissociation. I don’t lose consciousness or memory or have any shaking or stuff like that. The episodes are over in around 20 minutes as the feeling fade away.I’m really curious if the reason is pure anxiety (I have general anxiety disorder) or maybe something else.What makes me think about it is the fact that the episodes are sudden and apparently not related to stress.
27.answer: I would appreciate any information you can give me.

28.question: Female and Male, age 26 and 27. Female with epilepsy, male no medical diagnosis. Female on Keppra and Lamotrigine.My husband and I lived in a nice little basement suite for 3 years. Wishing a couple months of moving in, I developed epilepsy (unrelated head injury). Because of this I began taking medications. Not that long after I started to get morning sickness (without being pregnant). Every day for 2 years I woke up nauseous and vomited half of those times. It was believed it was my medication as epilepsy meds are pretty rough sometimes. About 6 months after moving in, my husband began waking up with nausea about 50% of the mornings. He has a high stress job and we believed it to be anxiety. In addition to that, we adopted our old cat about a year after moving in. He has a few medical issues and takes medication morning and night. He would vomit 5/7 mornings a week. The vet believed this to be part of his medical issues. All of that lined up until we moved 2 weeks ago. None of us have been sick since. As in, our last bouts of being sick was the day we woke up in our old place and moved. No nausea, no vomiting, not a dry heave in sight. If it was just one of us, it could be psychosomatic. I’d even be willing to believe that if it was both humans. But why the cat too?If it wasn’t the medication, anxiety and cat’s diagnosis, what was happening in that house???TLDR: 2 adults and a cat experienced nausea and vomiting for years, stopped instantly the day we moved.EDIT: Thank you all so much for the answers. It has made me very relieved that we left and we plan to take action. The house is for sale, which is why we moved, so we are going to inform the current owner, the real estate agent as well as the tenants who lived above us. We are also looking at our other options around ensuring this is properly taken care of so no one else gets hurt. I’ll also follow up when it sells to ensure the new owner didn’t get left with the fall out.Thank you all again!

29.question: 22 M, 150 lb, 5'8", white, myoclonus and "brain zaps" for the last two months. No history of seizures or epilepsy.Two months ago, while taking 10 mg fluoxetine daily, I decided to take some recreational substances. I can't undo this and am sober now so please don't give me too hard a time about this. I consumed 8 beers, 5 grams of kratom powder, and 50 mg of THC. The night before this, I had taken essentially the same combination minus the THC. I felt pretty much fine and fell asleep, maybe a little woozy from all the substances. However, I woke up early in the AM twitching. I didn't feel feverish or seriously unwell, so I didn't go to the doctor (I also don't have a GP right now).The twitching has persisted for the last two months. It's only when I'm sitting or lying down. It's gotten somewhat better over this time, but is worse when I'm tired or have coffee. I also experience the "brain zaps" seen in SSRI discontinuation syndrome. On a bad day, I'll twitch up to once a minute. Over the last two months, I also have seen a general shift away from twitching and toward "brain zaps."I haven't gone into urgent care or set a new appointment with a GP (which would be in, like, 2024) because I read there's no real treatment for the SSRI discontinuation brain zaps, and the twitching doesn't really get in the way that much. But I sort of notice that whenever I twitch I lose focus, which is concerning.Does this sound like something that will continue to slowly go away, or have I given myself epilepsy? My one interpretation is that I probably had mild serotonin syndrome and that combined with abruptly stopping my the fluoxetine could cause my symptoms, and that it'll just go away sooner or later. On the other hand, maybe I had a really severe seizure while I was asleep and now I have given myself epilepsy. I don't know if you can tell, but I will feel really bad if I have permanently disabled myself with drugs, but I guess any way you slice it, these are mild, localized seizures, right?
29.answer: The person is asking if they have given themselves epilepsy by stopping their fluoxetine and experiencing twitching and brain zaps.

30.question: My little sister, age 12, was diagnosed with epilepsy for the last 1 year. She has been taking necessary medications for its cure and prevention. However, she has been ill for the last few days and we ran a few tests waiting to get reports tomorrow. It's 3am now and she has been acting and moving her body weirdly while sleeping for the last hour, we're suspecting she's having nocturnal epilepsy. Moreover, she has been telling us she feels tremor in her stomach for the past 3 days. It would be really nice if anyone could answer the following questions    What could be the general cause of any epilepsy such as this?    What precautions should we take as a family or her as an individual to ensure a speedy cure or preventions?    What should we do or ensure when she has this during sleeping?    What habits should be changed to reduce risks of serious injuries by epilepsy?

31.question: I had a brain surgery 12 years ago to remove an AVM on the right side of my brain. A few years after the surgery, I was put back on epilepsy meds after I had a seizure. I've had seizures in clusters since then. That's the background, but my question isn't regarding epilepsy.My concern: I tried to get into weightlifting. However, every time I try to use my left shoulder, it just falls over. Same thing goes with left arm exercises- it just starts trembling and becomes useless after about 5 reps. Exercises I cannot do include shoulder presses, lat pulldowns, shoulder presses, dumbbell curls. Shoulder presses and dumbbell curls are the main exercises that show my problem. Even with ten reps of 5 pounds my arm starts falling over and becomes completely useless. I tried this for weeks without any progress. I can do leg exercises completely fine. Further, I have uneven arms and shoulders. I had my neurologist check for scoliosis, which I do not have. She told me my weakness is a result of brain surgery, which I don't know can cause this sort of limitation, especially because it doesn't get in the way of everyday tasks. I only notice it when trying to lift. I did some research, and came across something called hemiparesis. I'm wondering if this could be the issue/result of the brain surgery and is something my doctor didn't consider. If this is the condition, or if it isn't, is there anything I can do to fight this limitation? Could there be some type of treatment I can do to help with this? My information: Male, 22 years old, 5'5,
31.answer:
I had a brain surgery 12 years ago to remove an AVM on the right side of my brain. A few years after the surgery, I was put back on epilepsy meds after I had a seizure. I've had seizures in clusters since then. That's the background, but my question isn't regarding epilepsy.

My concern: I tried to get into weightlifting. However, every time I try to use my left shoulder, it just falls over. Same thing goes with left arm exercises- it just starts trembling and becomes useless after about 5 reps. Exercises I cannot do include shoulder presses, lat pulldowns, shoulder presses, dumbbell curls. Shoulder presses and dumbbell curls are the main exercises that show my problem. Even with ten reps of 5 pounds my arm starts falling over and becomes completely useless. I tried this for weeks without any progress. I can do leg exercises completely fine. Further, I have uneven arms and shoulders. I had my neurologist check for scoliosis, which I do not have. She told me my weakness is a result of brain surgery, which I don't know can cause this sort of limitation, especially because it doesn't get in the way of everyday tasks. I only notice it when trying to lift. I did some research, and came across something called hemiparesis. I'm wondering if this could be the issue/result of the brain surgery and is something my doctor didn't consider. If this is the condition, or if it isn't, is there anything I can do to fight this limitation? Could there be some type of treatment I can do to help with this?

32.question: I’m a 22 year old female and I have quite a track sheet of medical issues. I’m posting on here because I’m not sure if they are related and I really don’t know which road to go down.I’ve had ruptured ovarian cysts consistently since I was 12. every time I ovulate. I’ve been on birth control since I was 13 because of that. I have insanely painful periods and I know my hormones are out of wack but I’ve never been diagnosed officially with PCOS or endometriosis but I think I could have either one. not sure.I got diagnosed with epilepsy last February after two grand mal seizures on the same day. coincidentally(?) I had just gotten off birth control to try and heal my body naturally. my seizures seem to align with my menstrual cycle. I’m on Keppra and it’s controlling my tonic clonic seizures but I have breakthrough absence seizures 3x a week. originally my first EEG only showed right temporal lobe seizures but my most recent EEG showed right and left temporal lobe and left frontal lobe seizures.while I was in the epilepsy monitoring unit last week for a 7 day EEG during a pretty intense grand mal seizure my heart rate hit 275 bpm. I’ve always felt little heart flutters but this was intense. I have a Holter monitor now, and I was diagnosed with supraventricular tachycardia. I’m getting an ablation next week. the flutters happen after every seizure but sometimes just on their own without seizure activity.can someone please help me connect the dots, or point me in the direction of someone who can help? I’m really up for any suggestions right now because I want to go back to my normal life. thank you!
32.answer: i'm a 22 year old female and i have quite a track sheet of medical issues. i've had ruptured ovarian cysts consistently since i was 12. every time i ovulate. i've been on birth control since i was 13 because of that. i have insanely painful periods and i know my hormones are out of wack but i've never been diagnosed officially with polycystic ovary syndrome or endometriosis but i think i could have either one. not sure.

33.question: After standing from a prolonged period of sitting (especially when looking at a screen) I have 'episodes' which include spasms and staring. These occur multiple times a day, and I have had an ambulatory eeg. This has been happening for the last 4 years approximatelyThese came back to show that I don't have epilepsy, however my brain waves slow down and they suspect that I have mild cerebal hypoxia.My question is how bad is mild cerebal hypoxia because when severe, it can be very serious. Does the fact that it happens so frequently flag a matter of concern for my brain or general health?I have researched a little about this, but there's not much on mild cerebal hypoxis nor the frequency at which they occur in my personal case. I will be seeing a cardiology specialist at some point, but the waiting period could be very long.Information about myself: 19 male and have type 1 diabetes (since February 2016). Also I had a blood test in December, with all normal results. Apart from this, I have no other known medical conditions and am in relatively good shape.
33.answer: I am a 19 year old male with type 1 diabetes. I have had mild cerebal hypoxia for the last 4 years. I have had an ambulatory eeg which came back to show that I don't have epilepsy.

34.question: Currently on no medications, BW is normal other than some minor indication of anemia and malnourishment (low folate, hemotacrit, hemoglobin, vitamin d, sodium) high albumin.Family history of a wide variety of mental health conditions as well as cancer, diabetes, heart disease, and polycistic kidneys.Began approximately 4 years ago. Started having severe headaches with tingling and numbness in the face and limbs as well as weakness. Had motor ticks that were uncontrollable and sometimes painful due to their jerking motion. Had an mri that showed nothing other than white matter. Started having fainting spells that lasted for around 3 months before these dissipated. Visited a cardiologist during these fainting spells and they had determined there was nothing wrong with my heart. Had first convulsions during tonsil surgery which the doctors had said were a result of them trying to bring me off of sedation, they ended up having to re-sedate me for a few hours (no memory of this occurrence). The doctors who had done the surgery advised me to visit a neurologist since this would not have happened without a neurological problem present. Visit the neurologist that had diagnosed my migraines and was referred for an EEG. EEG showed normal brain activity and doctors said there were no findings that indicated anything wrong and there was nothing they could do for me. Motor ticks still present. Started having a strange sensation in head which were sometimes, but not always, accompanied by convulsions with loss of consciousness until current times. One of the most recent occurrences was when pulled over by a cop after dark(i was a passenger) and (i’m assuming) the flashing lights caused me to collapse and convulse (i wouldn’t consider this a reaction to stress since I have been pulled over during the daytime and had no issues). These convulsions most frequently occur when under the influence of substances, though they do occur at times when I am sober. Constant fatigue which may be due to anemia, and sleep 12 hours or more each night. Issues with long-term and short-term memory, as well as weakness in the limbs. Also have had gastrointestinal issues which i’m not sure if they are relevant or not: nausea and stomach pain after eating anything. Have had some issues with UTI’s. All doctors I have visited have told me there is nothing wrong and make me feel as if they just believe i’m looking for free pills(or a hypochrondiac) but I am still having these issues so i’m not sure where to go from here. pls help
34.answer:
The text provided is a detailed account of a person's medical history and symptoms. The individual has been experiencing various health issues, including headaches, fainting spells, convulsions, and seizures. They have been diagnosed with migraines and have been referred to a neurologist for an EEG. The person has also mentioned experiencing seizures, convulsions, and motor ticks, which have been present since childhood.

The individual has a family history of mental health conditions, cancer, diabetes, heart disease, and polycystic kidney disease. They have also mentioned experiencing a wide range of symptoms, including fatigue, gastrointestinal issues, and sleep disturbances. The seizures and convulsions have been triggered by various stimuli, such as flashing lights and stress.

The medical history and symptoms suggest that the individual may have a neurological condition, possibly related to seizures or migraines. The EEG results and the neurologist's diagnosis of migraines may provide further insight into the underlying cause of the symptoms.

If the individual is experiencing seizures, it is essential to consult with a neurologist to determine the underlying cause and appropriate treatment. The neurologist may recommend further testing, such as an MRI or CT scan, to rule out other potential causes of the seizures.

In addition to the neurological issues, the individual has also mentioned gastrointestinal issues, which could be related to the seizures or migraines. It is essential to address these gastrointestinal symptoms to ensure overall health and well-being.

The individual's family history and the presence of various symptoms suggest that they may have a neurological condition. Seeking a second opinion from a neurologist or a specialist in epilepsy may provide further guidance and treatment options.

In conclusion, the individual's medical history and symptoms indicate a possible neurological condition, possibly related to seizures or migraines. It is essential to consult with a neurologist to determine the underlying cause and appropriate treatment. Addressing gastrointestinal issues and seeking a second opinion may also be beneficial.

35.question: Hi all, I don’t know if Im looking in the right place but wanted to get some advice I have these “fits” where for about 10 seconds I can’t control my left side of my body or speak, it usually cause my arm to go up in the air, and my face to scrunch up, I am fully conscious and aware of what is happening during these episodes but I can’t control them, I am able to tell when I am about to have one, they normally happen when I stand up to fast, and jumped unexpectedly, or when I’m very nervous, I have had an EEG and an MRI scan about 4 years ago nothing showed up and no epilepsy was diagnosed either. I am not on any medication or anything, my doctor could not diagnose me and just told me to live a healthy lifestyle. I am just desperate to put in the right direction to try find a diagnosis and a solution as it is so embarrassing and it affects my day to day life. Thank you for your time
35.answer:
Hi,

I am not a doctor, but I can tell you that this sounds like a seizure. It is possible that you have a condition called "benign essential blepharospasm", which is a type of epilepsy that affects the muscles around the eyes.

I would recommend talking to your doctor about your symptoms and getting a referral to a neurologist. The neurologist can perform a thorough evaluation and determine if you have a seizure disorder. If you do have a seizure disorder, there are treatments available that can help you manage your symptoms.

I hope this helps! Let me know if you have any other questions.

For instance "lf you have X specific kind of epilepsy, or if you aren't taking X medication you can take them" Does the dose matter? I have read people say that would have seizures when microdosing but not when doing high doses. How does that work? Thank you so much!

37.question: I am 20M (age,sex) and currently on lamotrigine (150mg/day)I was ‘diagnosed ’ with epilepsy over two years ago. (When I was 18) I have never been evaluated for adhd.In the two years I started noticing some attention problem. (Adhd-like symptom).. Being distracted by other things, etc sometimes it could be ‘fixated’ to something even it’s not important and I was Chasing deadlines for assignments etc. I just cannot get my mind off those shits and start procrastinating things that are very important .I tried different methods such as setting my phone’s wall paper to a photo I took, the view of a famous university I’ve been looking forward to admit to. It only worked for a very short period of time. Not until the very last moment then I starts to regret and do whatever I can to complete the assignment/ important things.These behaviors is driving me crazy, also my GPA.I feel very nervous about meeting the conditional offer from the famous university because all of this. I really needed the offer and cannot afford losing it.I spoke to a counselor at my college and she thought, despite she doesn’t think I have adhd, but considering I have epilepsy. Maybe I could seek advice from a doctor, but a specialist consultation can cost a lot…

I really needed the offer and cannot afford losing it.I spoke to a counselor at my college and she thought, despite she doesn’t think I have adhd, but considering I have epilepsy. Maybe I could seek advice from a doctor, but a specialist consultation can cost a lot…

38.question: Hey, so I am male, early 30s, white. Currently taking : Lamictal 400mg Fluoxetine 10mg Omeprazole 40mg Gabapentin 300mg 3x day as needed Vitamin D DX : Bipolar type 2 Social phobia (not sure exactly how my psych phrased it) Anxiety Abdominal epilepsy Acid reflux Tobacco (on/off), marijuana use, almost never drink or use any other drugs. I will do my best to be brief. I have had serious mental health issues since I was a child. First suicide attempt was at 7. Institutionalized at 15 for suicidal ideation, and have had therapy since then. I restarted medications at 21. I have had a lot of bad experiences with medical professionals. Very abusive docs when institutionalized. My last doctor told me to treat my bipolar disorder with a multivitamin. The doctor before prescribed me an anti depressant, had a manic episode, then changed to lamictal 100mg. He also called me a drug seeker because I wanted muscle relaxers to treat a weird medical episode that was causing severe neck pain. This turned out to be abdominal epilepsy. I have used urgent cares on rare occasion to get antibiotics, etc. But I haven't had a pcp since I was 20. How can I find a PCP that is comfortable working with mental health patients? What do I need to have done to get on track? I am aware that I am extremely high risk for suicide, between bipolar, loss of a sibling to suicide, childhood sexual abuse. I feel it's more important than ever to get a grip on my physical health so I can have a long life with my wife and my parents, and live to take care of them in their golden years. Currently see a therapist and a psych for med management. I'm also working with my therapist now to work through my problems with seeking medical care. Any other questions I am happy to ask.
38.answer: The user is asking for help in finding a PCP who is comfortable working with mental health patients. They are also asking for advice on how to get on track with their physical health.

39.question: My bf is a 33M, 220 lbs, history of epilepsy, high cholesterol, has high blood pressure on occasion, ADD, allergy to augmentin, and kiwi. He takes lamotrigine, phenobarbital, Lamictal. He vapes, never drinks, and smokes marijuana on occasion. He hasn't had a seizure in three years fortunately. He went to the Dr yesterday and his Dr told him his med levels are at a level 2 when they should be at around a 7. Dr showed him that the levels dropped to dangerous levels in three years despite an increase in meds in those years. Any insight in what this could be? He's waiting on more blood tests.
39.answer: I'm a 23F. I'm concerned about my bf's health.

40.question: Age: 21 Sex: Female (But I go by He/Him) Height: 5'3 Weight: 106lbsOver the past few months I've been seeing a psychiatrist and she's put me on numerous pills. The first set of pills were Wellbutrin XL 300mg (One I'd already been taking) Venalafaxine ER 37.5mg, Hydroxyzine HCL 25mg, and Ondansetron 4mg. So far my only "diagnosed" issues are depression and a very severe panic/ anxiety disorder so these were meant to help me avoid panic attacks, mood swings, depression and nausea. However, I also explained that sometimes I smoke weed, she said I should avoid it, but occasionally it'd be fine. Same with Alcohol. So far alcohol has been just fine, but when I did weed It was a horrifying experience for me and my family. My body wouldn't stop shaking, all of my muscles felt tight and for some period of time I couldn't move and my breathing was very forced? I also was hallucinating bad. I kept asking my mom to look at my stomach because there was an air bubble that would travel to my heart and kill me. And I was so afraid I was going to die, but my mom kept assuring me that I was fine and that I was probably just tripping and that I needed to sleep. But I was so scared and didn't want to die alone so I slept in her room. It's been a few weeks since then and I haven't touched anything weed related since. But I still feel... Like ever since then I'm not exactly the same? I've been more suicidal than I've ever been in my life, and my muscles and joints feel bruised and I can barely stand to go grocery shopping my body feels so tired and in pain like I've run a marathon. Like I explained this to my psych and she didn't really seem to care. She's now got me on Oxcarbazepine 150mg that I take 2 times daily, along with everything else I was taking. I still have to take the Venalafaxine, but I'm weaning off of it. But so far I am still anxious, suicidal, and in more pain than I've ever been. And every now and then I'm seeing things like a weird grey cloud with a face in my bedroom or I'll think my hands are turning grey when they aren't.

41.question: As a preface, just want to include that I do have a doctor's appointment scheduled for these issues, but just wanted to get other people's opinions to see if I'm overthinking things. 5'10, about average weight, no drug use except nicotine. These symptoms precede any nicotine use, and seem unaffected by it. I have no history of seizures in early childhood, although a lot of the symptoms I list below have affected me since I was about 10. I do seem to have a family history with epilepsy, although I don't know all of the details. A few weeks back, I was reading a book -- and at one point, the author went into detail about Temporal Lobe Epilepsy. Interested by the concept, I looked it up, and found that many of the symptoms seem to line up with what I had called my migraine auras for years. Random tastes or smells, always enjoyable but never lasting for more than 5 seconds. Bursts of euphoria for absolutely no reason, gone within a minute or two. Strong dissociation at times, linked to no negative events, just out of nowhere. I thought this was interesting but didn't investigate it further until I thought about my sleep issues. If I don't sleep well, and attempt to nap later in the day, sleeping is sometimes nearly impossible. I'll instead be essentially semi-conscious, in a dream-like state, seeing random events unfold. When I "wake up" from these, my body feels as if it's buzzing, I feel completely exhausted, and I have no memory of the specific things I saw other than they occurred. I have no idea how long these moments last. And, the last issue, also sleep related and usually occurs again if I'm tired and attempt to nap -- I'll be able to fall asleep, but as I wake up, I'll feel locked-in, similar to sleep paralysis. I feel that same buzzing again, throughout my head and torso, and my head particularly seems to move around quickly. A couple weeks back this resulted in me (luckily, not too painfully) hitting my head against the wall. I only truly remembered that happening the next evening. As far as I remember, I went back to sleep after it happened with no further incidents. Thanks for any advice or opinions you may have :)
41.answer: I'm not sure if I'm overthinking things, but I'm also not sure if I'm not. I've been experiencing these symptoms for years, and I've never been diagnosed with anything. I've been to a doctor, but they've never been able to tell me what's wrong.

42.question: Male 31 non smoker 6’1” 250lbs, no history of epilepsy/seizuresI have always had sensitivity to lights while driving, especially at night. Things such as normal car headlights and signals have not caused a problem, however when it’s been raining or wet it causes the lights to be reflected off the pools of water it often disorients me and causes a dizzy feeling. I am in An area where it doesn’t rain now and yesterday had to drive through a tunnel covered with a crazy amount of LED lights, and with them reflecting off the cars I became almost instantly overwhelmingly dizzy and nauseous and had to pull over for 15 minutes for it to stop. I am not sure what is causing it, but I am afraid to drive at night or in certain areas because of this issue.
42.answer:
The question is:

What is causing the dizziness and nausea?

The answer is:

Rain and wet conditions.

43.question: Hello :) 26, male, 5'9, 87kg, Indian, generalised epilepsy for eight years, currently taking lamotrigine; I drink and live in the UK. I've had generalised epilepsy since I was 14, and it hasn't improved. I've had the same neurologist since I was diagnosed, and he told me nothing different to this date. It sucks because the only thing he ever tells me is they don't know the cause. At this age, it's still shit that I'm still not allowed to drive, I have seizures about once a month, and it worries me when I travel abroad or even at work. I would like to see if you guys have any advice, any different opinions or anything else that could help me. Thank you very much :)

44.question: 22F, 5’5, 173lb, whitehi there! weird thing happened last night and i’m nervous and hoping someone might have some input for me. i recently started taking prozac (10mg) in conjunction with lamictal (125mg) (which i’ve been on for about 6 weeks) for MDD. i’ve had a huge decrease in appetite which has led to me forgetting to eat a lot. yesterday i ate very little - almost nothing, without realizing. i was smoking weed with my partner and i started to feel really unwell. i have a low tolerance so i didn’t think much of it. i remember telling him i wanted to lay down, and next thing i knew i woke up to him holding me and saying my name over and over. he asked me a bunch of questions about my surroundings and personal information (address, birthday, etc.) to make sure i was aware and coherent. he said i was sitting there, mentioned i wanted to lay down, and then my body stiffened/seized up and i slid down the chair backwards until i was on the floor and he started trying to wake me up. he said in total, i was out for less than a minute, but he was worried i was having a seizure. while i was out, i was having what felt like a short lucid dream where i was rolling down a mountain, if that’s important. when i came back to my senses, i was sweating a lot, and was nauseous. i laid on the floor for a little bit until i felt okay, and then went to bed. today i feel fine.i figured i just fainted bc i hadn’t eaten and i was smoking, but i know serotonin syndrome can cause seizures so i’m just feeling very anxious and wondering if i’m worrying over nothing. i’ve never fainted or had a seizure so i don’t really know what either one feel like.
44.answer: i’m a 22 year old white female. i’m 5’5 and 173lbs. i’m on prozac 10mg and lamictal 125mg. i’m on a low dose of prozac and i’m not sure if it’s the right dose. i’m also on a low dose of lamictal. i’m not sure if i’m having a seizure or if i’m having a serotonin syndrome. i’m just really nervous and hoping someone can give me some input.

45.question: Hi. I’m 22F. So 5 years ago I was diagnosed with epilepsy after a full-tonic (like a stereotypical?) seizure having had myoclonic seizures constantly for like 2 years before then. No one took me seriously until the major one. During the diagnosis and since, I was constantly asked to describe what I NOW know are myoclonic seizures, but no one ever said they were. I was on Lamotrigine (around 100mg morning and night) until 2020, then was on Keppra (500mg morning and night). In 2021 I was told that since i hadn’t had a seizure in over 3 years I could stop medication (which wasn’t actually true- I hadn’t had a full on seizure in over 3 years but I still had myoclonic ones when having sleeping problems but no neurologist seemed to understand that they were seizures?). The ECG came back clear but I was too nervous to stop meds but in 2022 I was recommended to stop meds again and the ECG was clear again too, so I did. From May 2022 I was absolutely fine with zero issues at all. Then one night in September, I was only able to sleep 2 hours and had dozens of myoclonic seizures until I had a full on seizure. Completely out of the blue. I was then put on 250mg Keppra morning and night but the new neurologist prescribed Lamotrigine…but only 25mg every morning. I was fine on 500mg Keppra/day but then ran out and hadn’t been told how to make the switch, so I just replaced the meds. In the days right after, I’d have a small myoclonic seizure while trying to fall asleep but I thought I was just trying to adjust. A few days later though, I woke up (after minimum 6 hours of sleep) and had dozens of myoclonic seizures only seconds apart and I spent hours trying to fight off a major seizure. After a few hours break we went to A&E because I was begging for meds I wasn’t prescribed. They just said to take 25mg Lamotrigine at night so I immediately did. When I went to bed the constant myoclonic seizures resumed from midnight until 5-6am. All day/night I thought I’d have to end my life rather than go more days like this. The next few days got gradually better and the pharmacists were horrified I was prescribed so badly. But ever since then, I have been on 100mg Lamotrigine + 1g Keppra morning then 1g Keppra at night and regularly have myoclonic seizures while trying to fall asleep so have to take Clobazam. Sorry for the novel, but why has everything gone so downhill??

46.question: Hi all, yesterday I (20F) went to the beach. I was feeling fine, talking to my family, and then all I remember is laying on my side in the sand with a lot of concerned people around me. Apparently I seized up, fell back into the sand, and was clutching at the air with a pained expression before falling completely unconscious and drooling foam (doing some of my own research, I'm guessing this was a tonic-clonic seizure, as I was "out" for several minutes after the muscle spasms). After waking up, I was unable to tell the medics my age — it was as if I'd forgotten what numbers were, it was scary.I was promptly taken to the nearest ER and spent the rest of the afternoon and early evening doing blood tests, a urine test, an EKG, and a CT scan. So far, everything looks normal. I was given fluids and eventually discharged. Later this week I'll have an MRI done, and I have an unrelated neurologist appointment to follow up about chronic headaches (I will definitely mention the seizure).Since being discharged I've been pretty steady on my feet, just tired and achy in my arms and back. I have some mild tremors in my hands and legs but those predate the seizure. I'm limiting my screen time and will not be driving for a little while. I've also been instructed to lower my dosage of Wellbutrin as it carries a higher seizure risk. I'm staying with my family over the summer, thus I won't be alone if something were to happen at home. My partner is an EMT which gives me more comfort if something were to happen at her place.My first question is: how common is this type of thing? I'd only heard of epilepsy causing seizures before yesterday, and all of my testing so far shows no abnormalities. My second question is: should I wait a while before returning to hobbies like dancing or using my sewing machine? I'm a very careful person but even then, I don't want to endanger myself unnecessarily. Thanks in advance!

47.question: Hello, I am 24 and I was diagnosed with epilepsy around 2 years ago, and prior to this I thought epilepsy was 1) you were born with it, and 2) it was caused due to flashing lights. My epilepsy seemingly comes out of nowhere, it is not caused by ANYTHING. (I don't know my specific weight, this is just for the subreddit rules - I'm the average weight for a UK male) Absolutely nothing seems to triggers my seizures, I have only ever had 1 seizure in public, and that was the first one I ever had. I have been clubs, I have been night clubs, flashing lights do not effect me, they just seemingly occur out of nowhere, and I was hoping someone could give me more information on this kind of thing.

48.question: I am not a doctor, but I know my body and I am no fool. I also try to avoid going to the doctor unless necessary, so I try to make sure I have to go before I do. My doctors tend to mark me up to either being a hypochondriac or having drug seeking behaviour.For example: I have very severe epilepsy, and the Keppra I am on is no longer working; I am having multiple seizures in a row every month along with, almost constant myoclonic jerks in my legs. I asked my doctor to please change me from the Keppra about 6 months ago, when it first started showing signs of no longer working. Last month I had 9 focal-to-generalized seizures without becoming aware between them.In short, pharmaceutical companies tell me to ask my doctor about certain meds, but when I do, they blow me off.Bonus Question: What do you recommend for these seizures? They are almost always triggered by hormones, stress level, and being asleep.Thanks in advance!
48.answer: I am not a doctor, but I know my body and I am no fool. I also try to avoid going to the doctor unless necessary, so I try to make sure I have to go before I do. My doctors tend to mark me up to either being a hypochondriac or having drug seeking behaviour. My doctors tend to mark me up to either being a hypochondriac or having drug seeking behaviour.

49.question: My partner (28M) used to have over 50 grand mal seizures a month after a car accident. They had their front temporal lobe removed a couple of years ago to reduce them and that seemed to help. I’ve haven’t known him long and we have only been living together for about 4 weeks. He had one grand mal a couple of weeks ago and I made sure to catch him before he fell, laid him on his side, and stayed with him until he came to. I informed his grandmother as well because he lived with her before this and I honestly was scared. Well, today he has had 1 cognitive seizure this morning and now we’re up to four grand mal seizures. His grandmother is telling me this happens sometimes but it’s seriously scaring me. He’s in pain and his family is saying not to call an ambulance because he will lose his license and I know he would hate me for that. I’ve been trying to make sure that he stays hydrated and takes his medicine in the small windows that he’s awake and coherent, but he’s being a jerk to me when he is awake, saying that I’m bothering him and he “doesn’t need any medicine”. I love this person with all my heart and want to get him help, but his family would know more about his condition than I would. I really don’t know what to do. Any advice would be appreciated
49.answer: The person who wrote this is asking for help with their partner who has had seizures. They are worried about their partner and want to know what to do.

50.question: gender (male) age (17) can anxiety or stress lead to epilepsy and seizures without being prone to one all your life ?

51.question: My daughter 13(F).She is 5'6", 120 pounds, white--she's lost 5 pounds in the past 3-4 months and is already quite skinny. She's been complaining about abdominal pain (located 1/2 inch above her belly button and across the whole abdominal area, but has had bouts of localized pain more to the right of her navel) since April and it's worsened in the last 3 months significantly.It's worse after eating and after any activity (including just walking around). She says the pain feels stabbing/throbbing-like. She is not eating much because she does not feel hungry and complains of a feeling like there is a lump in her throat. Today, she had multiple instances of dizziness/lightheadedness and fell down from it.She has an extensive medical history, but her current diagnoses are: Epilepsy (since she was 2, more specifically Abnormal Doose Syndrome) Neurogenic Bladder & Bowel Disorder (not Dysfunctional Elimination Syndrome) Raynauds ADHD Sensory Processing Disorder Neuropathy Temperature Regulation Issues Anhidrosis Generalized Anxiety Insomnia (clinically diagnosed) Additional information on Neurogenic Bladder & Bowel Disorder:She can void on her own, but her bladder is 2x larger than it should be and she was catheterized for 4 years before she figured out how to void on her own. She still does not have proper sensation and VCUG has shown her bladder does not "respond" when full, but she's figured out how to tell and how to make herself void well enough catheterization is no longer necessary.Her colon is also 2x larger than it should be with multiple redundencies, but the placement of them would place scar tissue too close to the rectum and would cause a higher chance of blockages and cause the colon to stretch out again. Her internal sphincters do not work properly (for both bladder and bowel). She is on a high regiment of medications and still only eliminates about every other day.Current Medications: Linzess (290mg/daily) for bowels Lactulose (30mg/twice daily) for bowels    Bisacodyl (5mg every other day and 10mg on the other days) for bowels  MagCalm (magnesium citrate, 4mg/daily) + 32mg/monthly for mini cleanout of bowels (increased to 68mg for full cleanout of bowels)Lamictal (20mg/twice daily) for epilepsyKeppra (1250mg/twice daily) for epilepsyClonidine (5mg/daily) for insomniaDaily vitamin + iron fortification for childrenAll blood work has come back normal so far:CBC Differential with PlateletComp. Metabolic Panel (14)Celiac Test—Negative Sed Rate, WestergrenCMP14+eGFRTSH+Free T4Lipid PanelVitamin D, 25-Hydroxy (this was slightly low) t-Transglutaminase (tTG) IgAt-Transglutaminase (tTG) IgGImmunoglobulin A, Qn, SerumC-Reactive Protein, QuantH. Pylori Test—Negative I know this is a lot of info, but I am open to hearing any ideas. She's in constant pain, it never goes away, just goes from at least a 4 up to 9-10 on the pain scale. No fevers, no vomiting, no nausea.
51.answer: The reason I'm asking is that I'm concerned that she may have a bowel obstruction or a stricture.

52.question: Not sure if this is allowed- (20F/medical MJ patient/white) I've been trying to get this figured out for YEARS now, no one takes me seriously. Does anyone know about temporal lobe epilepsy? For years I've had severe deja vu (I can literally tell what's going to happen before it does) that is accompanied by severe nausea and head tingling/pressure. The pressure is in the occipital lobe and temples, and it never lasts longer than 10 minutes. It'll go on multiple times a day for a week, then disappear for months. I keep logs of what happens during, before and after and how long they last JUST in case. It's not that bad but it really makes me feel like pure shit and like I'm going to die when it happens
